Topics.Strand: Module 1 – Development of practical skills in chemistry

Sub_topics.description: Demonstrate and apply knowledge and understanding of experimental design to solve problems set in a practical context, including selecting suitable apparatus, equipment and techniques for the proposed experiment; apply scientific knowledge from across the specification to the practical context (HSW3).
Identify variables that must be controlled in an experiment where appropriate, and explain why control is necessary for valid conclusions.
Evaluate whether a proposed experimental method is appropriate to meet expected outcomes; judge fitness for purpose, limitations, and whether the design addresses the question (HSW6).

Topics.Strand: Module 1 – Development of practical skills in chemistry

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Correct use of apparatus and techniques
Sub_topics.description: Demonstrate and apply understanding of how to use a wide range of practical apparatus and techniques correctly, as required across the specification and as outlined for the Practical Endorsement (HSW4).
Select and use appropriate units for measurements in practical work and reporting results (M0.0).
Present observations and data in an appropriate scientific format (tables, annotated observations, recorded readings) suitable for analysis and evaluation (HSW8).

Topics.Strand: Module 1 – Development of practical skills in chemistry

Sub_topics.description: Process, analyse and interpret qualitative and quantitative experimental results, including reaching valid conclusions where appropriate; distinguish trends, patterns, and outcomes supported by evidence (HSW5).

Use appropriate mathematical skills to analyse quantitative data, selecting suitable calculations and methods as required by the chemistry context; competence aligned to Section 5 mathematical skills (HSW3).
Use significant figures appropriately when recording and reporting measurements and calculated values; understand rounding consistent with measurement precision (M1.1).

Plot and interpret suitable graphs from experimental results, including selecting and labelling axes with appropriate scales, quantities and units; measure gradients and intercepts correctly (M3.2, M3.3, M3.4, M3.5).

Topics.Strand: Module 1 – Development of practical skills in chemistry

Sub_topics.description: Evaluate experimental results and draw conclusions that are justified by evidence; relate conclusions to the aim/hypothesis and data quality (HSW6).
Identify anomalies in experimental measurements or observations; decide whether data points are inconsistent and require investigation or exclusion with justification.
Explain limitations in experimental procedures, including methodological constraints and apparatus limitations that affect reliability/validity.
Discuss precision and accuracy of measurements and data; calculate/interpret margins of error, percentage errors, and uncertainties associated with apparatus and combined measurements (M1.3).
Suggest improvements to procedures and apparatus to refine experimental design, improve accuracy/precision, manage variables and reduce uncertainties (HSW3).

Topics.Strand: Module 1 – Development of practical skills in chemistry

Sub_topics.description: Apply investigative approaches and methods to practical work, including solving problems in a practical context; demonstrate independent thinking and appropriate decision-making during investigations (HSW3).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Safe use of equipment and materials
Sub_topics.description: Safely and correctly use a range of practical equipment and materials; identify potential hazards and understand how to minimise risk in chemistry practicals (HSW4).
Follow written practical instructions accurately to carry out procedures as intended, with appropriate sequencing and attention to detail.
Make and record observations and measurements accurately and appropriately during practical work (HSW8).
Keep appropriate records of experimental activities (e.g. methods, raw data, observations, processing, conclusions) as required for practical competency evidence.
Present information and data in a scientific way, including appropriate tables, graphs, units, significant figures, and clear written communication.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Use software/tools for processing and reporting
Sub_topics.description: Use appropriate software and tools to process data, carry out research and report findings; include digital handling of data such as graphing and calculations (M3.1, HSW3).
Use online and offline research skills including websites, textbooks and other printed scientific sources of information to support practical work and chemical understanding.
Correctly cite sources of information used in research and reporting, using appropriate citation methods suitable for scientific work.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Use a wide range of instruments/techniques
Sub_topics.description: Use a wide range of experimental and practical instruments, equipment and techniques appropriate to the knowledge and understanding included in the specification (HSW4).

Topics.Strand: Module 1 – Development of practical skills in chemistry

Sub_topics.description: Use appropriate apparatus to record a range of measurements including mass, time, volume of liquids and gases, and temperature (HSW4).
Use a water bath, electric heater or sand bath safely and effectively for heating in practical procedures (HSW4).
Measure pH using pH charts, pH meter, or pH probe/data logger appropriately; understand suitable use and recording (HSW4).
Carry out titration using burette and pipette with correct technique (rinsing, reading meniscus, repeat titres) and appropriate recording (HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Distillation and heating under reflux setup
Sub_topics.description: Set up and use apparatus for distillation and for heating under reflux, including safe assembly of glassware with retort stand and clamps (HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Qualitative tests (ions and organic functional groups)
Sub_topics.description: Perform qualitative tests for ions and organic functional groups using correct test-tube scale procedures and interpret observations (HSW4).
Carry out filtration including use of fluted filter paper and filtration under reduced pressure (vacuum filtration) where appropriate (HSW4).
Use a volumetric flask accurately to make up a standard solution to a known concentration, including correct filling to the calibration mark and mixing (HSW4).
Use acid–base indicators appropriately in titrations of weak/strong acids with weak/strong alkalis; choose suitable indicator ranges and recognise end points (HSW4).
Purify a solid product by recrystallisation, including dissolving, hot filtration if needed, crystallisation, and drying (HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Purify liquids and use separating funnel
Sub_topics.description: Purify a liquid product, including correct use of a separating funnel for liquid–liquid separation and collection of layers (HSW4).
Use melting point apparatus to determine melting points of solids and interpret melting point as an indicator of purity (HSW4).
Use thin layer chromatography or paper chromatography, including safe solvent use, spotting, developing, and interpreting separated components (HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Electrochemical cells: set up and measure voltage
Sub_topics.description: Set up electrochemical cells and measure voltages safely and accurately; record and interpret readings (HSW4).
Safely and carefully handle solids and liquids including corrosive, irritant, flammable and toxic substances; apply appropriate safety measures and risk controls (HSW4).
Measure rates of reaction by at least two different methods, e.g. an initial rate method (clock reaction) and a continuous monitoring method; collect suitable time and/or continuous data (HSW4).
Explain isotopes as atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons and therefore different masses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Subatomic particles in atoms and ions
Sub_topics.description: Determine numbers of protons, neutrons and electrons in atoms and ions given atomic number, mass number and ionic charge.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Relative isotopic mass vs relative atomic mass
Sub_topics.description: Explain relative isotopic mass (mass compared with 1/12 of a 12C atom) and relative atomic mass (weighted mean mass compared with 1/12 of a 12C atom); understand the carbon-12 standard. Definitions required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mass spectrometry: isotopic masses and abundances
Sub_topics.description: Use mass spectrometry data to determine relative isotopic masses and relative abundances of isotopes; knowledge of instrument not required; limited to singly charged ions (M0.2, M1.2, M3.1).
Calculate relative atomic mass, Ar, from isotopic abundances and isotopic masses provided by mass spectrometry (M0.2, M1.2, M3.1); limited to singly charged ions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mr and relative formula mass calculations
Sub_topics.description: Calculate relative molecular mass, Mr, and relative formula mass from relative atomic masses; use Mr for simple molecules and relative formula mass for giant structures. Definitions not required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Predict ionic charge from periodic table position
Sub_topics.description: Predict ionic charge from an element’s position in the periodic table for forming common ions; use this to write formulae of ionic compounds.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Recall common ion names and formulae
Sub_topics.description: Recall names and formulae of ions: NO3−, CO3²−, SO4²−, OH−, NH4+, Zn2+, Ag+. Assume ‘nitrate’ = NO3− and ‘sulfate’ = SO4²− unless stated. Other ion charges will be provided.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Write ionic compound formulae from charges
Sub_topics.description: Write formulae of ionic compounds from ionic charges, combining ions in ratios to give charge neutrality; apply to familiar and unfamiliar examples.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Balanced chemical and ionic equations with state symbols
Sub_topics.description: Construct balanced chemical equations (including ionic equations) with state symbols for studied reactions and unfamiliar reactions given appropriate information (M0.2).
Explain and use the term amount of substance, expressed using the formula of the substance (e.g. amount of NaCl; amount of O2).
Explain and use the mole (mol) as the unit of amount of substance (M0.0, M0.1, M0.2, M0.4).
Explain and use the Avogadro constant NA = 6.02 × 10^23 mol−1 as number of particles per mole; value provided on Data Sheet (M0.0, M0.1, M0.2, M0.4).
Explain and use molar mass as mass per mole with units g mol−1; relate molar mass to Ar/Mr and mass calculations (M0.0, M0.1, M0.2, M0.4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Molar gas volume at RTP (24.0 dm3 mol−1)
Sub_topics.description: Explain and use molar gas volume as gas volume per mole (dm3 mol−1); use molar gas volume at RTP (24.0 dm3 mol−1) from Data Sheet (M0.0, M0.1, M0.2, M0.4).

Use the terms empirical formula (simplest whole-number ratio of atoms) and molecular formula (actual numbers of each atom type in a molecule). Definitions not required, but meaning must be understood.

Calculate empirical formulae and molecular formulae from composition by mass or percentage composition by mass and relative molecular mass; include elemental analysis data contexts (M0.2, M2.2, M2.3, M2.4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hydrated salts and water of crystallisation
Sub_topics.description: Use the terms anhydrous, hydrated, water of crystallisation; calculate formula of a hydrated salt from percentage composition, mass composition, or experimental results (M0.2, M2.2, M2.3, M2.4; PAG1).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mole calculations: mass, gas volume, solution concentration
Sub_topics.description: Perform calculations using amount of substance (mol) involving mass, gas volume, and solution volume and concentration; express concentration in mol dm−3 and g dm−3 (M0.0, M0.1, M0.4, M1.1, M2.2, M2.3, M2.4).
Use the ideal gas equation pV = nRT for gas calculations; express quantities in SI units; R provided on Data Sheet (M0.0, M0.1, M0.4, M1.1, M2.2, M2.3, M2.4).
Use stoichiometric relationships in quantitative calculations based on balanced equations, including limiting reagents/amount ratios where relevant (M0.2).
Calculate percentage yield of a reaction and related quantities using actual vs theoretical yield based on stoichiometry (M0.2, M1.1, M2.2, M2.3, M2.4).
Calculate atom economy of reactions and related quantities; interpret in context of reaction equations (M0.2, M1.1, M2.2, M2.3, M2.4).
Describe techniques and procedures required during experiments that measure masses, volumes of solutions and gas volumes accurately; link to quantitative experimental skills (PAG1; HSW4).
Explain benefits for sustainability of developing chemical processes with high atom economy, particularly in industry and resource efficiency (HSW10).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Common acids and alkalis; H+ and OH− in aqueous solution
Sub_topics.description: Recall formulae of common acids (HCl, H2SO4, HNO3, CH3COOH) and common alkalis (NaOH, KOH, NH3); explain acids release H+ ions in aqueous solution and alkalis release OH− ions in aqueous solution.
Explain qualitatively strong vs weak acids in terms of relative dissociation/ionisation in water (extent of H+ release).
Describe neutralisation as reaction of H+ and OH− to form H2O; write appropriate ionic equation and relate to acid–alkali reactions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Acids with bases/carbonates/oxides/alkalis to form salts
Sub_topics.description: Explain neutralisation as reaction of acids with bases including carbonates, metal oxides and alkalis to form salts (and water/CO2 where relevant); write full equations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Standard solution preparation and acid–base titration technique
Sub_topics.description: Describe and apply techniques/procedures for preparing a standard solution of required concentration and carrying out acid–base titrations (PAG2; HSW4).

Carry out structured and non-structured titration calculations using experimental results for familiar and unfamiliar acids and bases; use stoichiometry, concentrations, volumes, significant figures (M0.1, M0.2, M1.1, M1.2, M2.2, M2.3, M2.4).
Apply rules for assigning and calculating oxidation numbers for atoms in elements, compounds and ions; include oxidation number of O in peroxides and H in metal hydrides.
Write chemical formulae using oxidation numbers to determine charge balance and stoichiometry; communicate using oxidation-state reasoning (HSW8).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Roman numerals for oxidation state in names
Sub_topics.description: Use Roman numerals to indicate oxidation number magnitude in compound/ion names when elements have multiple oxidation states (e.g. iron(II), iron(III)); convert between names and formulae including chlorate(I), chlorate(III); assume nitrate and sulfate as NO3− and SO4²− unless specified (HSW8).
Define oxidation and reduction in terms of electron transfer and changes in oxidation number; apply to examples from s-, p- and d-block elements.

Write full equations for redox reactions of metals (s-, p-, d-block e.g. Mg, Al, Fe, Zn) with acids to form salts and hydrogen; limited to reactions producing salt + H2; ionic equations not required; note reactions with HNO3 or conc. H2SO4 may be considered elsewhere.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Interpret/predict redox via oxidation numbers and electrons
Sub_topics.description: Interpret redox equations (including those in 2.1.5(e)) and unfamiliar redox reactions to predict oxidation numbers, electron loss/gain and overall changes; use oxidation-state bookkeeping (M0.2).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Electron capacity of first four shells
Sub_topics.description: Recall and use the number of electrons that can fill the first four electron shells (principal energy levels).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Atomic orbital definition and electron spins
Sub_topics.description: Define an atomic orbital as a region around the nucleus that can hold up to two electrons with opposite spins; relate to electron configuration models (HSW1, HSW7).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Shapes of s and p orbitals
Sub_topics.description: Recognise and describe the shapes of s-orbitals and p-orbitals as used in chemical bonding and electron structure models.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Numbers of orbitals and electron capacities in subshells
Sub_topics.description: State the number of orbitals in s, p and d subshells and hence the maximum number of electrons in each subshell (s, p, d).
Fill orbitals for the first three shells and the 4s and 4p orbitals in order of increasing energy; use correct energy ordering for electron configurations.
For orbitals of the same energy, place electrons singly before pairing; use ‘electrons in boxes’ representations consistent with Hund’s rule.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Electron configuration of atoms up to Z=36
Sub_topics.description: Deduce electron configurations of atoms up to atomic number Z = 36 using subshell notation (e.g. O: 1s2 2s2 2p4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Electron configuration of ions (s/p-block) up to Z=36
Sub_topics.description: Deduce electron configurations of ions (limited to s- and p-block up to Z = 36) given atomic number and ionic charge; apply electron gain/loss to subshell notation.
Explain ionic bonding as electrostatic attraction between positive and negative ions; construct dot-and-cross diagrams for ionic compounds.
Explain solids of ionic compounds as giant ionic lattices with oppositely charged ions strongly attracted in all directions (e.g. NaCl).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Properties of ionic compounds from structure/bonding
Sub_topics.description: Explain melting/boiling points, solubility, and electrical conductivity of ionic compounds in solid, molten (liquid) and aqueous states in terms of ionic structure, strong attractions, and ion mobility (HSW1).
Define a covalent bond as the strong electrostatic attraction between a shared pair of electrons and the nuclei of the bonded atoms.
Construct dot-and-cross diagrams for molecules/ions showing single covalent bonding; include lone pairs as needed (up to six electron pairs around central atom).

Construct dot-and-cross diagrams for molecules/ions showing multiple covalent bonding (double/triple as required), including appropriate shared pairs and lone pairs (up to six electron pairs around central atom).
Construct dot-and-cross diagrams showing dative covalent (coordinate) bonding; identify electron pair donation from lone pair to an electron-deficient species.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Average bond enthalpy as bond strength measure
Sub_topics.description: Use the term average bond enthalpy as a measure of covalent bond strength; understand larger average bond enthalpy implies stronger bond. Definition/calculations not required here (covered in 3.2.1(f)).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Electron pair repulsion and bond angles (up to 6 pairs)
Sub_topics.description: Predict shapes and bond angles for molecules/ions with up to six electron pairs (including lone pairs) around central atom using electron pair repulsion; compare repulsive strengths of bonded pairs vs lone pairs; draw 3-D diagrams (M4.1, M4.2; HSW1,2).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Common molecular shapes: linear to octahedral
Sub_topics.description: Use electron pair repulsion to explain shapes: linear, non-linear (bent), trigonal planar, pyramidal, tetrahedral, octahedral; know lone pairs repel more than bonded pairs; recall common bond angles e.g. CH4 109.5°, NH3 107°, H2O 104.5°.

Define electronegativity as ability of an atom to attract bonding electrons in a covalent bond; interpret Pauling electronegativity values; recognise trend increases towards F across a period and up a group (HSW1,2).
Explain polar bonds and permanent dipoles in molecules with covalently bonded atoms of different electronegativity; show dipole direction and partial charges.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Polar molecules and overall dipole vs shape
Sub_topics.description: Explain when a molecule is polar in terms of bond dipoles and molecular shape; distinguish cases where dipoles cancel (e.g. CO2) vs not (e.g. H2O).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Van der Waals forces: permanent and induced dipoles
Sub_topics.description: Explain intermolecular forces based on permanent dipole–dipole interactions and induced dipole–dipole (London dispersion) interactions; recognise both may be called van der Waals’ forces (HSW1,2).
Explain hydrogen bonding as intermolecular bonding between molecules containing N, O or F and the H atom of –NH, –OH or HF; include role of lone pairs.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Anomalous properties of water from H-bonding
Sub_topics.description: Explain anomalous properties of water resulting from hydrogen bonding, including (i) density of ice vs water, and (ii) relatively high melting and boiling points (HSW1).
Explain solid structures of simple molecular lattices as covalently bonded molecules attracted by intermolecular forces, e.g. I2 and ice.

Explain melting/boiling points, solubility and electrical conductivity of covalent compounds with simple molecular lattice structures in terms of intermolecular forces and lack of mobile charged particles.

Explain periodic table arrangement by increasing atomic (proton) number; elements in periods show repeating trends in physical and chemical properties (periodicity); elements in groups have similar chemical properties; understand development/extension of periodic table as scientific knowledge (HSW1,7,11).
Describe periodic trend in electron configurations across Periods 2 and 3; relate to shell/subshell filling and valence electrons (see also 2.2.1(d)).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Classify elements as s-, p-, d-block
Sub_topics.description: Classify elements into s-block, p-block and d-block based on the subshell being filled in ground-state electron configuration.

Define first ionisation energy as removal of 1 mol of electrons from 1 mol of gaseous atoms; understand successive ionisation energy concept; use in explanations and predictions (definition required for first only).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ionisation energy trends across periods and down groups
Sub_topics.description: Explain trends in first ionisation energies across Periods 2 and 3 and down a group in terms of attraction between nucleus and outer electron, nuclear charge, atomic radius, shielding; include anomalies due to s vs p subshell energies (Be→B) and p-orbital repulsion (N→O) (M3.1; HSW1,2).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Use successive IE to deduce shells and group
Sub_topics.description: Use successive ionisation energies to predict number of electrons in each shell and hence deduce the group of an element; interpret large jumps in IE (M3.1).
Explain metallic bonding as strong electrostatic attraction between cations (positive ions) and delocalised electrons.
Explain metals as giant metallic lattice structures; no details of cubic or hexagonal packing required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Giant covalent structures: diamond, graphite, graphene, silicon
Sub_topics.description: Explain solid giant covalent lattices of carbon (diamond, graphite, graphene) and silicon as networks of atoms bonded by strong covalent bonds; link to strength and conductivity; recognise graphene applications (HSW1,9).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Properties of giant metallic and giant covalent lattices
Sub_topics.description: Explain melting/boiling points, solubility and electrical conductivity of giant metallic and giant covalent lattices in terms of structure and bonding: particle types, relative force/bond strength, and mobility of particles/charge carriers as appropriate (HSW1).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Melting point trends across Periods 2 and 3
Sub_topics.description: Explain variation in melting points across Periods 2 and 3 in terms of changes in structure and bonding (giant metallic → giant covalent → simple molecular lattice); relate to bonding models and intermolecular forces (M3.1).
Explain Group 2 outer shell s2 electron configuration and loss of these two electrons in redox reactions to form 2+ ions.
Describe and compare reactivities of Group 2 metals Mg → Ba via redox reactions with oxygen; write appropriate equations and observations where relevant.
Describe and compare reactivities of Group 2 metals Mg → Ba via redox reactions with water; write appropriate equations; understand trends in reaction vigour.
Describe and compare reactivities of Group 2 metals Mg → Ba via redox reactions with dilute acids; limited to salt + hydrogen formation; write full equations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Explain Group 2 reactivity trend using ionisation energies
Sub_topics.description: Explain trend in reactivity down Group 2 in terms of first and second ionisation energies; write equation for second ionisation energy change though definition not required (M3.1).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Group 2 oxides with water; pH trend
Sub_topics.description: Explain action of water on Group 2 oxides and approximate pH of resulting solutions; describe trend of increasing alkalinity down group.
Explain use of Ca(OH)2 as a base in agriculture to neutralise acid soils; write relevant neutralisation equations.
Explain use of Mg(OH)2 and CaCO3 as antacids to neutralise stomach acid; write relevant equations including carbonate reactions where appropriate.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Halogens as diatomic molecules; boiling point trend
Sub_topics.description: Explain halogens as diatomic molecules and explain trend in boiling points of Cl2, Br2, I2 in terms of increasing induced dipole–dipole (London dispersion) forces (see also 2.2.2(k)).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Halogen electron configuration and halide ions
Sub_topics.description: Explain outer shell s2p5 electron configuration of halogens and that in many redox reactions they gain one electron to form 1− ions; emphasise electron transfer and oxidation number changes; include full and ionic equations where appropriate.
Describe and interpret trend in reactivity of Cl2, Br2, I2 shown by reactions with other halide ions; include expected colour changes in aqueous and organic solutions; write ionic equations.
Explain trend in halogen reactivity (Cl2 > Br2 > I2) via decreasing ease of forming 1− ions in terms of attraction, atomic radius, and electron shielding.

Define disproportionation as oxidation and reduction of the same element; illustrate with (i) reaction of chlorine with water (water treatment), (ii) reaction of chlorine with cold, dilute NaOH(aq) (bleach formation), and (iii) analogous reactions; write equations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Chlorine in water treatment: benefits vs risks
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate benefits of chlorine use in water treatment (killing bacteria) against risks (toxic chlorine gas hazards; possible risks from formation of chlorinated hydrocarbons); consider alternatives and ethical decisions (HSW9,10,12).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Test for halide ions with Ag+ and NH3
Sub_topics.description: Describe precipitation reactions (with ionic equations) of Cl−, Br−, I− with Ag+(aq) followed by reaction with aqueous NH3; use observations as test for halide ions; complexes with NH3 not required beyond observations (PAG4; HSW4).

Carry out and interpret qualitative analysis on test-tube scale for CO3²− by reaction with H+(aq) forming CO2(g); write ionic equation and state observation (effervescence). Sequence of tests: carbonate first (PAG4; HSW4).

Carry out and interpret test for SO4²− by precipitation with Ba2+(aq); write ionic equation and state observation; perform after carbonate test due to insolubility issues (BaCO3 insoluble). Sequence: sulfate second (PAG4; HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Tests for halide ions in analysis sequence
Sub_topics.description: Apply halide tests for Cl−, Br−, I− as part of qualitative analysis sequence after carbonate then sulfate; use Ag+(aq) precipitation and NH3 to distinguish; record observations (PAG4; HSW4).
Carry out and interpret test for NH4+ by warming with NaOH(aq) to form NH3; recognise ammonia (e.g. smell, turns damp red litmus blue); write ionic equation where appropriate (PAG4; HSW4).
Explain that chemical reactions may be accompanied by enthalpy changes; identify exothermic reactions with ΔH negative and endothermic reactions with ΔH positive.
Construct enthalpy profile diagrams showing relative enthalpy of reactants and products and the overall ΔH; include correct energy level depiction (M3.1).
Explain activation energy qualitatively as minimum energy required for a reaction; use enthalpy profile diagrams to show Ea for forward (and reverse where appropriate) reactions (M3.1).
Explain and use standard conditions and standard states (physical states under standard conditions), taking standard conditions as 100 kPa and stated temperature 298 K.
Use enthalpy change of reaction ΔrH as enthalpy change associated with a stated equation; interpret ΔrH in thermochemical equations.
Define and use standard enthalpy change of formation ΔfH as formation of 1 mol of a compound from its elements in their standard states under standard conditions; apply in calculations and cycles.
Define and use standard enthalpy change of combustion ΔcH as complete combustion of 1 mol of a substance; apply to fuels and Hess cycles.
Define and use enthalpy change of neutralisation ΔneutH as formation of 1 mol of water from neutralisation; apply to calorimetry contexts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Calorimetry: determine ΔH using q = mcΔT
Sub_topics.description: Determine enthalpy changes directly from experimental results using q = mcΔT; handle units and conversions; apply to suitable calorimetry experiments (M0.0, M0.2, M2.2, M2.3, M2.4; PAG3).

Explain average bond enthalpy as breaking 1 mol of specified bonds in gaseous molecules; formal definition not required but meaning must be understood; recognise actual bond enthalpies may differ from averages.
Explain exothermic and endothermic reactions in terms of enthalpy changes associated with breaking (endothermic) and making (exothermic) covalent bonds; relate net ΔH to balance of these energies.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Calculate ΔH using average bond enthalpies
Sub_topics.description: Use average bond enthalpies to calculate enthalpy changes and related quantities for reactions; apply stoichiometry and unit consistency (M0.0, M0.2, M2.2, M2.3, M2.4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hess’ law cycles using combustion data
Sub_topics.description: Apply Hess’ law to construct enthalpy cycles and calculate ΔrH indirectly from enthalpy changes of combustion; definitions of Hess’ law not required; unfamiliar cycles will be provided (M0.0, M0.2, M1.1, M2.2, M2.3, M2.4, M3.1; HSW2).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hess’ law cycles using formation data
Sub_topics.description: Apply Hess’ law to construct cycles and calculate ΔrH indirectly from enthalpy changes of formation; interpret provided cycles (M0.0, M0.2, M1.1, M2.2, M2.3, M2.4, M3.1).
Use Hess’ law with unfamiliar enthalpy cycles provided to determine unknown enthalpy changes; set up equations correctly and solve (M0.0, M0.2, M1.1, M2.2, M2.3, M2.4, M3.1).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Techniques for direct and indirect ΔH determination
Sub_topics.description: Describe techniques and procedures used to determine enthalpy changes directly and indirectly (including those covered later in 5.2.1(c)); include practical considerations and method reliability (M3.1, M3.2; PAG3; HSW4).
Explain effect of concentration (and gas pressure) on rate of reaction in terms of collision theory and frequency of collisions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Calculate rate from gradient of graphs
Sub_topics.description: Calculate reaction rate from gradients of graphs of a physical quantity vs time; suitable quantities include concentration, gas volume, mass etc.; interpret slope as rate (M3.1, M3.2, M3.5).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Catalyst not used up; increases rate
Sub_topics.description: Explain role of a catalyst in increasing reaction rate without being used up in the overall reaction; distinguish from stoichiometric reactants.
Explain that a catalyst provides an alternative reaction pathway with lower activation energy; illustrate using enthalpy profile diagrams.
Define and distinguish homogeneous catalysts (same phase as reactants) and heterogeneous catalysts (different phase).

Explain economic importance of catalysts and sustainability benefits: lower operating temperatures, reduced energy demand from fossil fuel combustion, reduced CO2 emissions; evaluate toxicity risks of some catalysts (HSW9,10).
Describe techniques and procedures to investigate reaction rates including measuring mass, gas volumes and time; plan/execute suitable experiments (PAG9; HSW4).
Explain qualitatively the Boltzmann distribution of molecular energies and its relationship to activation energy; interpret effect of Ea threshold (M3.1).
Use Boltzmann distributions to explain qualitatively how increasing temperature increases proportion of molecules with energy ≥ Ea, increasing reaction rate (M3.1; HSW1,2,5).
Use Boltzmann distributions to explain catalyst effect as lowering Ea, increasing proportion of molecules with energy ≥ Ea at a given temperature, increasing reaction rate (M3.1; HSW1,2,5).
Explain dynamic equilibrium in a closed system: forward rate equals reverse rate and concentrations of reactants/products remain constant.

Apply Le Chatelier’s principle to homogeneous equilibria to deduce qualitatively effects of changes in temperature, pressure or concentration on position of equilibrium; definition not required (HSW1,2,5).
Explain that a catalyst increases rates of both forward and reverse reactions equally and therefore does not change equilibrium position (but reaches equilibrium faster).
Describe techniques/procedures to investigate changes to equilibrium position with changes in concentration and temperature; qualitative effects only; include observation and interpretation (HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Industry: compromise between equilibrium and rate
Sub_topics.description: Explain importance to chemical industry of compromise between equilibrium yield and reaction rate when choosing operating conditions; include safety/economics context (e.g. Haber) (HSW6).
Write expressions for equilibrium constant Kc for homogeneous reactions; calculate Kc from provided equilibrium concentrations; units not required (M0.2, M1.1, M2.3, M2.4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Estimate position of equilibrium from Kc magnitude
Sub_topics.description: Estimate position of equilibrium qualitatively from magnitude of Kc (e.g. very large Kc implies products favoured); qualitative estimation only (M0.3).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: IUPAC naming of organic compounds (spec scope)
Sub_topics.description: Apply IUPAC nomenclature rules to systematically name organic compounds limited to functional groups in this specification; know first ten alkane names and corresponding alkyl groups; e.g. CH3CH2CH(CH3)CH2OH is 2-methylbutan-1-ol (HSW8, HSW11).
Interpret and use general formulae as simplest algebraic formula for a member of a homologous series (e.g. alkane CnH2n+2); definitions not required.

Interpret and use structural formulae showing minimal detail of atom arrangement (e.g. butane CH3CH2CH2CH3 or CH3(CH2)2CH3); understand conventions: carboxyl group written as COOH; ester group as COO.
Interpret and use displayed formulae showing relative positions of atoms and bonds (e.g. ethanol displayed with all bonds).

Interpret and use skeletal formulae removing H atoms from alkyl chains to show carbon skeleton and functional groups; use standard ring symbols for cyclohexane and benzene; recognise as communication tool (M4.2; HSW8).
Use and interpret homologous series as series of organic compounds with same functional group where successive members differ by CH2; definition required for homologous series.
Use and interpret functional group as group of atoms responsible for characteristic reactions of a compound.
Use and interpret alkyl groups of formula CnH2n+1; use R to represent alkyl groups and other non-reacting fragments as appropriate.
Use and interpret aliphatic compounds as carbon/hydrogen in straight chains, branched chains or non-aromatic rings.
Use and interpret alicyclic compounds as aliphatic compounds arranged in non-aromatic rings with or without side chains.
Use and interpret aromatic compounds as those containing a benzene ring.

Use and interpret saturated as containing single C–C bonds only; unsaturated as presence of multiple carbon–carbon bonds including C=C, C≡C and aromatic rings; note usage distinct from broader ‘degree of saturation’.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Use general formula to predict member formula
Sub_topics.description: Use the general formula of a homologous series to predict the molecular formula of any member of that series.
Explain structural isomers as compounds with same molecular formula but different structural formulae; determine possible structural formulae given a molecular formula (M4.2).
Explain homolytic covalent bond fission: each bonding atom receives one electron from the shared pair forming two radicals; represent radicals appropriately in mechanisms.
Explain heterolytic covalent bond fission: one bonding atom receives both electrons from the bond; relate to formation of ions/dipoles in polar reactions.
Define radical as species with an unpaired electron; use single dot (•) to represent radicals in mechanisms and equations (e.g. Cl•, CH3•). Dots not required for diradicals (e.g. O).
Describe curly arrow as movement of an electron pair showing heterolytic fission or covalent bond formation; half-curly arrows are not required for this spec’s radical substitution mechanism.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Drawing reaction mechanisms with curly arrows and dipoles
Sub_topics.description: Draw reaction mechanisms using diagrams to show movement of an electron pair with curly arrows and relevant dipoles; arrows start from bond, lone pair, or negative charge; include dipoles where relevant (HSW1,2,8).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: σ bonds in alkanes and free rotation
Sub_topics.description: Explain alkanes as saturated hydrocarbons containing single C–C and C–H bonds as σ-bonds (direct orbital overlap); describe free rotation about σ bonds; hybridisation not required (HSW1).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Tetrahedral geometry around carbon in alkanes
Sub_topics.description: Explain tetrahedral shape and bond angle around each carbon in alkanes using electron pair repulsion; draw 3-D diagrams (M4.1, M4.2; see also 2.2.2(g–h)).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Alkane boiling points: chain length and branching
Sub_topics.description: Explain variation in boiling points of alkanes with carbon chain length and branching in terms of London (induced dipole–dipole) forces and surface area effects (M3.1; see also 2.2.2(k)).
Explain low reactivity of alkanes with many reagents due to high bond enthalpy and very low polarity of σ bonds; link to stability and non-polar nature (HSW1; see also 2.2.2(j)).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Complete vs incomplete combustion of alkanes
Sub_topics.description: Write and interpret equations for complete combustion of alkanes (CO2 + H2O) and incomplete combustion in limited oxygen; explain dangers from CO formation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Radical substitution of alkanes with halogens (mechanism)
Sub_topics.description: Describe and apply radical substitution of alkanes with chlorine/bromine under UV, including mechanism steps: initiation (homolytic fission), propagation, termination; represent radicals with dots; half-curly arrows not required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Limitations of radical substitution in synthesis
Sub_topics.description: Explain limitations of radical substitution for synthesis: mixture of products due to further substitution and substitution at different positions in carbon chain; relate to selectivity issues.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: π bond and σ bond in alkenes; restricted rotation
Sub_topics.description: Explain alkenes as unsaturated hydrocarbons with C=C comprising a π bond (sideways p-orbital overlap) and a σ bond (direct overlap); explain restricted rotation about π bond; hybridisation not required (HSW1).
Explain trigonal planar shape and bond angle around each carbon in the C=C using electron pair repulsion; draw 3-D representations where appropriate (M4.1, M4.2).

Explain stereoisomers as same structural formula with different spatial arrangement; explain E/Z isomerism due to restricted rotation about C=C and requirement of two different groups on each carbon of C=C; explain cis–trans as special case where two substituents are the same.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: CIP priority rules for E/Z assignment
Sub_topics.description: Apply Cahn–Ingold–Prelog (CIP) priority rules to identify E and Z stereoisomers; note E≡trans and Z≡cis only consistently when H on each C; CIP for double/triple bonds within R groups not required (M4.2, M4.3).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Determine E/Z or cis–trans stereoisomers from structure
Sub_topics.description: Determine possible E/Z or cis–trans stereoisomers given structural formula; identify when isomerism is possible (M4.2, M4.3).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Alkene reactivity from π bond enthalpy
Sub_topics.description: Explain alkene reactivity in terms of relatively low bond enthalpy of π bond compared to σ bonds; relate to addition reactions.
Describe addition of hydrogen to alkenes in presence of suitable catalyst (e.g. Ni) to form alkanes; write equations and conditions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Halogen addition; bromine test for C=C
Sub_topics.description: Describe addition of halogens to alkenes to form dihaloalkanes; use bromine to test for unsaturation via decolourisation; write equations and relate to qualitative analysis.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hydrogen halide addition to form haloalkanes
Sub_topics.description: Describe addition of hydrogen halides (H–X) to alkenes to form haloalkanes; write equations and identify products for symmetrical/unsymmetrical alkenes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hydration of alkenes to alcohols (steam, acid catalyst)
Sub_topics.description: Describe addition of steam to alkenes in presence of acid catalyst (e.g. H3PO4) to form alcohols; write equations and state conditions (PAG7).
Define electrophile as an electron pair acceptor; apply to electrophilic addition mechanisms.

Describe and apply mechanism of electrophilic addition to alkenes via heterolytic fission; show curly arrows, carbocation intermediate; for halogen addition, carbocation or halonium ion intermediate acceptable (HSW1,2,8).

Use Markownikoff’s rule to predict major product of H–X addition to unsymmetrical alkenes; explain in terms of relative stability of primary/secondary/tertiary carbocation intermediates (no need to explain why stabilities differ) (HSW1,2,5).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Deduce addition polymer repeat unit from monomer
Sub_topics.description: Explain addition polymerisation of alkenes/substituted alkenes; deduce repeat unit structure from given monomer (show brackets and n).
Given a section of an addition polymer, identify the monomer that would produce it; relate to C=C opening and substituents.

Explain benefits for sustainability of processing waste polymers by (i) combustion for energy, (ii) use as organic feedstock to produce plastics/chemicals, (iii) removal of toxic products such as HCl during combustion of halogenated plastics (e.g. PVC) (HSW9,10).
Explain environmental benefits of developing biodegradable and photodegradable polymers: reduced dependency on finite resources and reduced persistent waste problems (HSW9,10).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Alcohol polarity, H-bonding, solubility and volatility
Sub_topics.description: Explain polarity of alcohols and, in terms of hydrogen bonding, explain water solubility and relatively low volatility compared with alkanes (see 2.2.2(l), 4.1.2(c)).
Classify alcohols as primary, secondary or tertiary based on carbon atom bearing –OH group and number of attached alkyl groups.
Write and interpret equations for combustion of alcohols; relate to fuels and energy release.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Oxidation of primary alcohols: aldehydes vs carboxylic acids
Sub_topics.description: Describe oxidation of primary alcohols using oxidising agent Cr2O7²−/H+ (K2Cr2O7/H2SO4): primary alcohols oxidise to aldehydes and then to carboxylic acids; control product using conditions (distillation vs reflux); use [O] in equations (PAG7).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Oxidation of secondary alcohols to ketones
Sub_topics.description: Describe oxidation of secondary alcohols with Cr2O7²−/H+ to form ketones; use [O] notation and appropriate conditions.
Explain resistance to oxidation of tertiary alcohols under specified oxidising conditions; recognise lack of reaction with dichromate under normal conditions.
Describe elimination of H2O from alcohols with acid catalyst (H3PO4 or H2SO4) and heat to form alkenes; write equations; mechanism not required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Substitution to haloalkanes using halide ions and acid
Sub_topics.description: Describe substitution of alcohols with halide ions in presence of acid (e.g. NaBr/H2SO4) to form haloalkanes; write equations; mechanism not required.
Describe hydrolysis of haloalkanes via substitution with aqueous alkali; write equations to form alcohols and halide ions/salts; recognise conditions (e.g. warm, reflux) where appropriate.

Describe hydrolysis of haloalkanes with water in presence of AgNO3 and ethanol to compare experimentally rates of hydrolysis of different C–X bonds; relate precipitate formation timing to rate (PAG7).
Define nucleophile as an electron pair donor; apply to nucleophilic substitution mechanisms.

Describe mechanism of nucleophilic substitution (SN2) in hydrolysis of primary haloalkanes with aqueous alkali; show curly arrows from nucleophile lone pair to carbon and from C–X bond to halide; include relevant dipoles (HSW1,2).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hydrolysis rate trend vs C–X bond enthalpy
Sub_topics.description: Explain trend in rates of hydrolysis of primary haloalkanes in terms of C–X bond enthalpies (C–F, C–Cl, C–Br, C–I); weaker bonds hydrolyse faster.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: CFCs, radicals and ozone depletion mechanism
Sub_topics.description: Explain production of halogen radicals by UV photodissociation of CFCs in upper atmosphere and resulting catalysed breakdown of ozone; write equations for (i) radical production (e.g. CF2Cl2 → CF2Cl• + •Cl) and (ii) catalytic cycle for ozone breakdown by Cl• (and other radicals e.g. •NO): •Cl + O3 → •ClO + O2; •ClO + O → •Cl + O2; construct analogous equations for stated radicals; relate to evidence and legislation (HSW9,10,11,12).
Use techniques and procedures for Quickfit apparatus including distillation and heating under reflux; understand safe setup and purpose of each method (PAG5; HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prepare and purify an organic liquid
Sub_topics.description: Prepare and purify an organic liquid including separating funnel separation of organic/aqueous layers, drying with anhydrous salt (e.g. MgSO4, CaCl2), and redistillation; apply appropriate technique (PAG5; HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Identify functional groups; predict properties/reactions (Module 4 set)
Sub_topics.description: For an organic molecule containing several functional groups (limited to those encountered in Module 4), identify each functional group and predict properties and reactions based on those groups (HSW3).

Devise two-stage synthetic routes for preparing organic compounds by applying transformations between all functional groups encountered up to this point (Module 4); interpret and use additional reaction info provided on exam papers when extending toolkit (HSW3).
Explain that infrared radiation causes covalent bonds to vibrate and absorb energy; link absorption to bond types and functional group identification.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: IR-active atmospheric gases and global warming link
Sub_topics.description: Explain absorption of IR by atmospheric gases with C=O, O–H, C–H bonds (e.g. CO2, H2O, CH4), suspected link to global warming and resulting changes to energy usage/policy (HSW9,10,11,12).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Identify alcohol by IR O–H peak
Sub_topics.description: Use an IR spectrum to identify an alcohol from O–H absorption peak; use provided IR data; note most organics show ~3000 cm−1 C–H peak (M3.1).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Identify aldehyde/ketone by IR C=O peak
Sub_topics.description: Use an IR spectrum to identify aldehydes/ketones from C=O absorption peak; use supplied IR absorption ranges (M3.1).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Identify carboxylic acid by IR C=O and broad O–H
Sub_topics.description: Use an IR spectrum to identify carboxylic acids from C=O absorption and broad O–H absorption; apply provided IR ranges (M3.1).
Interpret and predict IR spectra of familiar or unfamiliar substances using supplied data; restricted to functional groups studied in specification; use as evidence for structure (M3.1; HSW3,5).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: IR spectroscopy uses: pollution monitoring and breathalysers
Sub_topics.description: Explain use of IR spectroscopy to monitor air pollution gases (e.g. CO, NO from car emissions) and in breathalysers to measure ethanol; relate to evidence in legal contexts (HSW12).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mass spectrometry: molecular ion peak and molecular mass
Sub_topics.description: Use mass spectrum to identify molecular ion (M+) peak and determine molecular mass; limited to singly charged ions; recognise small M+1 peak from 13C; not expected to interpret mass spectra of organic halogen compounds; limited to compounds in this spec section (M3.1; HSW3,5).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mass spec fragmentation peaks and fragment ions
Sub_topics.description: Analyse fragmentation peaks to identify parts of molecular structures; suggest structures of fragment ions from m/z values and plausible cleavage patterns (M3.1; HSW3,5).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Deduce organic structure from combined data (EA, MS, IR)
Sub_topics.description: Deduce structures of organic compounds from combined analytical data: elemental analysis, mass spectra, IR spectra; limited to functional groups encountered so far; exclude halogen mass spec interpretation requirement (M3.1; HSW3,5,6).

Topics.Strand: Module 5 – Physical chemistry and transition elements

Sub_topics.description: Explain and use terms: rate of reaction, order, overall order, rate constant (k), half-life (t1/2), rate-determining step; relate to experimental kinetics and mechanisms.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Deduce orders from initial rates data
Sub_topics.description: Deduce reaction orders with respect to reactants from experimental (initial rates) data; interpret tables and ratios to infer m and n values (restricted to 0, 1, 2) (M0.2; PAG10).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Write rate equation from orders (rate = k[A]^m[B]^n)
Sub_topics.description: Construct a rate equation of the form rate = k[A]^m[B]^n from determined orders where m,n ∈ {0,1,2}; understand effect of zero order terms (M0.2; HSW8).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Calculate k and its units from rate equation
Sub_topics.description: Calculate rate constant k and related quantities from a rate equation; determine units of k from overall order and rate/concentration units; use correct unit conversions (M0.0, M0.1, M0.4, M1.1, M2.2, M2.3, M2.4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Order from concentration–time graph shape (0 or 1)
Sub_topics.description: From a concentration–time graph, deduce order (0 or 1) with respect to a reactant from curve shape (linear decrease vs exponential) (M0.1, M0.4, M1.1, M3.1–M3.5).
Calculate reaction rates from gradients (tangents) on concentration–time graphs (continuous monitoring); relate slope magnitude and sign to rate (M0.1, M0.4, M1.1, M3.1–M3.5).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: First order: constant half-life from concentration–time graph
Sub_topics.description: From concentration–time graph of a first order reaction, measure constant half-life t1/2 and recognise constancy of half-life as first-order characteristic (M3.1, M3.2).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: First order: k from half-life (k = ln 2 / t1/2)
Sub_topics.description: For a first order reaction, determine k from half-life using k = ln 2 / t1/2; no derivation required; recognise relationship to exponential decay [A] = [A0]e^(−kt) (M0.1, M0.4, M1.1, M2.3, M2.4, M2.5).

From a rate–concentration graph, deduce order (0, 1, or 2) with respect to a reactant from graph shape (constant, linear, curved); relate to initial rates method/clock reaction approximations (M0.1, M0.4, M1.1, M3.1–M3.5).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: First order: k from rate–concentration gradient
Sub_topics.description: Determine k for a first order reaction from gradient of a rate–concentration graph where rate = k[A]; interpret experimental rate–concentration data (M0.1, M0.4, M1.1, M3.1–M3.5).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Practical investigation: initial rates, continuous monitoring, colorimetry
Sub_topics.description: Describe techniques/procedures to investigate rates by initial rates and continuous monitoring, including use of colorimetry; plan and interpret kinetic experiments (PAG9, PAG10; HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Rate equation consistent with rate-determining step
Sub_topics.description: For a multi-step reaction, predict a rate equation consistent with a proposed rate-determining step; connect slow step molecularity to rate law assumptions (HSW1).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mechanism steps from rate law and overall equation
Sub_topics.description: Predict possible steps in reaction mechanism from given rate equation and overall balanced equation; identify intermediates and how steps sum to overall reaction (HSW1).
Explain qualitatively effect of temperature on reaction rate and hence on rate constant k using collision theory/energy distribution links (M0.3; see 3.2.2).

Use Arrhenius equation k = Ae^(−Ea/RT) to describe exponential relationship between k and temperature T; recognise parameters Ea (activation energy), A (pre-exponential factor), R (gas constant on Data Sheet); equations provided (M0.1, M0.4, M2.2–M2.5, M3.1–M3.4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Arrhenius plot to determine Ea and A
Sub_topics.description: Determine Ea and A graphically using ln k = −Ea/(RT) + ln A; interpret gradient and intercept from linear plot of ln k vs 1/T; handle units and significant figures; no need to explain physical meaning of A (M0.1, M0.4, M2.2–M2.5, M3.1–M3.4; HSW5).

Topics.Strand: Module 5 – Physical chemistry and transition elements

Sub_topics.description: Use and apply terms mole fraction and partial pressure in gas equilibria contexts; relate to mixture composition and total pressure.

Calculate quantities present at equilibrium given appropriate data (e.g. initial amounts, equilibrium amounts, K values, total pressure/volume as provided); set up ICE-style calculations without quadratic solving requirement (M0.2).
Describe techniques/procedures used to determine quantities present at equilibrium (not for Kp); include sampling, titration/spectroscopy where applicable (HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Kc and Kp expressions (homogeneous and heterogeneous)
Sub_topics.description: Write expressions for Kc and Kp for homogeneous and heterogeneous equilibria; omit solids and liquids (constant concentration) from expressions; include powers from stoichiometric coefficients (M0.2).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Calculate Kc and Kp including units (no quadratics)
Sub_topics.description: Calculate Kc and Kp (or related quantities) including determination of units; learners not required to solve quadratic equations; apply correct concentration/pressure units and conversions (M0.0, M0.1, M0.2, M0.4, M2.2, M2.3, M2.4).
Explain qualitative effect of changing temperature on equilibrium constants (Kc, Kp) for exothermic vs endothermic reactions; relate to van ’t Hoff concept qualitatively (M0.3).
Explain that equilibrium constants remain constant with changes in concentration, pressure, or presence of a catalyst (at constant temperature); apply to reasoning about equilibria (M0.3).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: How K controls equilibrium shifts under changes
Sub_topics.description: Explain how an equilibrium constant value controls equilibrium position when concentration, pressure, or temperature changes; connect K magnitude to extent of reaction and new equilibrium (M0.3).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Apply K reasoning to other equilibrium constants
Sub_topics.description: Apply principles from Kc/Kp to other equilibrium constants where appropriate (e.g. Ka, Kw), recognising analogous relationships and constraints.

Topics.Strand: Module 5 – Physical chemistry and transition elements

Sub_topics.description: Define Brønsted–Lowry acid as proton donor and base as proton acceptor; apply to acid–base reactions and equilibria (see also 2.1.4).
Use term conjugate acid–base pair; identify conjugate pairs in equations for acid–base equilibria.
Define and apply monobasic, dibasic and tribasic acids (number of protons donated per molecule) and relate to stoichiometry in neutralisation/titration contexts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ionic equations for acids with metals and bases
Sub_topics.description: Use ionic equations to show role of H+ in reactions of acids with metals and bases (including carbonates, metal oxides, alkalis); connect to modules 2.1.4 and 2.1.5 contexts.
Explain and use acid dissociation constant Ka as measure of extent of acid dissociation; link to weak vs strong acids (M0.1, M0.2, M0.4, M2.3, M2.4, M2.5).
Use relationship between Ka and pKa (pKa = −log Ka) for calculations and comparisons (M0.1, M0.4, M2.3, M2.4, M2.5).
Use pH = −log[H+] and [H+] = 10^(−pH) for converting between pH and hydrogen ion concentration (M0.1, M0.4, M2.2–M2.5; HSW8).
Use expression for ionic product of water Kw; relate [H+][OH−] to pH/pOH calculations and strong base pH (M0.1, M0.4, M2.2–M2.4).
Calculate pH and related quantities for strong monobasic acids assuming complete dissociation; use concentration and stoichiometry with [H+] (M0.1, M0.4, M2.2–M2.5).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: pH of strong bases using Kw
Sub_topics.description: Calculate pH and related quantities for strong bases using Kw and [OH−] to find [H+] and pH; apply log calculations (M0.1, M0.4, M2.2–M2.5).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Weak acid pH and Ka calculations with approximations
Sub_topics.description: Calculate pH, Ka or related quantities for a weak monobasic acid using approximations: [HA]eq ≈ [HA]undissociated (i.e. [HA] >> [H+]); [H+]eq ≈ [A−]eq; negligible dissociation of water; no quadratic solving required (M0.1, M0.4, M2.1–M2.5).
Explain limitations of Ka approximations for ‘stronger’ weak acids; recognise when [HA]eq ≈ [HA]undissociated no longer valid and why; evaluate impact on calculated values (M0.3; HSW6).
Define a buffer solution as a system that minimises pH changes on addition of small amounts of acid or base; relate to equilibrium/reservoir behaviour.
Describe formation of buffer from weak acid and its salt (conjugate base), e.g. CH3COOH/CH3COONa; understand components and their roles.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prepare buffer: excess weak acid + strong alkali
Sub_topics.description: Describe formation of buffer from excess weak acid and strong alkali, e.g. excess CH3COOH + NaOH giving mixture CH3COOH/CH3COO−.
Explain role of conjugate acid–base pair in controlling pH of an acid buffer, e.g. CH3COOH/CH3COO−; describe response to added H+ or OH− via equilibrium shifts.

Calculate pH of a buffer from Ka of weak acid and equilibrium concentrations of conjugate acid–base pair; calculate related quantities; use appropriate logs and approximations where valid (M0.1, M0.4, M2.2–M2.5).
Explain control of blood pH by carbonic acid–hydrogencarbonate buffer system; know buffer maintains blood plasma pH 7.35–7.45; relate to physiological importance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: pH titration curves: shapes for strong/weak combinations
Sub_topics.description: Sketch and interpret pH titration curves for strong/weak acids with strong/weak bases; explain curve features including buffer regions and equivalence pH; recognise no suitable indicator for weak acid/weak base titration (M3.1).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Choose indicators using indicator pH range
Sub_topics.description: Choose suitable indicators for titrations based on indicator transition pH range and the titration curve; justify indicator choice using equivalence point region (M3.1).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Indicator colour change as equilibrium shift (HA ⇌ A−)
Sub_topics.description: Explain indicator colour changes in terms of equilibrium shift between HA and A− forms of indicator (indicator as weak acid HA); relate to Le Chatelier’s principle and pH changes (M3.1).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Measure pH with a pH meter (technique)
Sub_topics.description: Describe techniques/procedures for measuring pH using a pH meter, including calibration/rinsing and correct electrode use; link to reliable data collection (PAG11; HSW4).

Topics.Strand: Module 5 – Physical chemistry and transition elements

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Lattice enthalpy definition and ionic bond strength
Sub_topics.description: Define lattice enthalpy of formation ΔLEH as formation of 1 mol of ionic lattice from gaseous ions; use as measure of strength of ionic bonding in giant ionic lattice; relate to melting point and stability (see 2.2.2).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Born–Haber cycles and lattice enthalpy calculations
Sub_topics.description: Use lattice enthalpy and relevant energy terms to construct Born–Haber cycles and perform calculations for simple ionic solids (e.g. NaCl, MgCl2). Relevant terms: ΔfH, ionisation energy, atomisation enthalpy, electron affinity. Definitions required for first ionisation energy and ΔfH only; apply conservation of energy (M2.2, M2.3, M2.4, M3.1; HSW2).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Enthalpy change of solution ΔsolH definition
Sub_topics.description: Define enthalpy change of solution ΔsolH as enthalpy change when 1 mol of solute dissolves; apply to dissolving ionic solids; infinite dilution details not required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Enthalpy change of hydration ΔhydH definition
Sub_topics.description: Define enthalpy change of hydration ΔhydH as enthalpy change when 1 mol of gaseous ions dissolves in water; apply to hydration energy concepts; infinite dilution details not required.

Use ΔsolH and relevant terms (ΔhydH and lattice enthalpy) to construct enthalpy cycles and carry out related calculations for ionic solids (e.g. NaCl, MgCl2); apply energy conservation (M2.2, M2.3, M2.4, M3.1; HSW2).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Effect of ionic charge and radius on ΔLEH and ΔhydH
Sub_topics.description: Explain qualitatively how ionic charge and ionic radius affect exothermic magnitude of lattice enthalpy and enthalpy change of hydration; higher charge/smaller radius gives more exothermic values due to stronger electrostatic attractions.

Topics.Strand: Module 5 – Physical chemistry and transition elements

Sub_topics.description: Explain entropy as measure of dispersal of energy in a system, greater when system is more disordered; use model to explain thermodynamic stability (HSW1).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Entropy magnitude: solids vs liquids vs gases
Sub_topics.description: Explain differences in entropy magnitude for solids, liquids and gases; relate to particle freedom and energy dispersal.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Entropy change and moles of gas
Sub_topics.description: Explain entropy changes for reactions with changes in number of gaseous molecules; relate to dispersal and sign of ΔS.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Calculate entropy change ΔS from standard entropies
Sub_topics.description: Calculate entropy change of system ΔS for a reaction from entropies of reactants and products; apply stoichiometric coefficients and units (M2.2, M2.3, M2.4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Feasibility depends on ΔH and TΔS
Sub_topics.description: Explain feasibility of a process depends on entropy term TΔS and enthalpy change ΔH; interpret competing effects; use in predictions (HSW1,5,6).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Gibbs free energy ΔG = ΔH − TΔS and feasibility
Sub_topics.description: Use Gibbs equation ΔG = ΔH − TΔS; calculate ΔG and related quantities; state that a process is feasible when ΔG is negative; use correct units (ΔH in J or kJ, ΔS in J K−1, T in K) (M0.0, M2.2, M2.3, M2.4; HSW5).
Explain limitations of ΔG feasibility predictions due to kinetics: negative ΔG does not guarantee fast reaction; consider activation energy and rate constraints (M0.3; HSW6).

Topics.Strand: Module 5 – Physical chemistry and transition elements

Sub_topics.description: Explain and use terms oxidising agent and reducing agent in terms of electron transfer/oxidation state changes (see also 2.1.5).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Construct redox equations using half-equations and oxidation numbers
Sub_topics.description: Construct balanced redox equations using half-equations and oxidation numbers; ensure electron balance and correct species, including acidic conditions where appropriate (M0.2).
Interpret and predict redox reactions involving electron transfer; use oxidation states, half-equations and feasibility reasoning.
Describe techniques/procedures for redox titrations including systems Fe2+/MnO4− and I2/S2O3²−; include endpoint recognition and suitable conditions; practical opportunities (HSW4).

Carry out structured and non-structured calculations from redox titration results for Fe2+/MnO4− and I2/S2O3²− and for non-familiar redox systems; apply stoichiometry, concentrations, volumes and significant figures (M0.1, M0.2, M0.4, M1.1, M1.2, M2.2, M2.3, M2.4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Standard electrode potential E° and hydrogen electrode
Sub_topics.description: Use term standard electrode (redox) potential E°; understand measurement relative to standard hydrogen electrode; E° data provided in exams.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Measure cell potentials: metal/non-metal with ions
Sub_topics.description: Describe techniques/procedures to measure cell potentials for metals or non-metals in contact with their ions in aqueous solution; for standard conditions use 1 mol dm−3 (PAG8; HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Measure potentials: same element ions different oxidation states with Pt
Sub_topics.description: Describe techniques/procedures to measure cell potentials involving ions of same element in different oxidation states using Pt electrode; solutions equimolar or 1 mol dm−3 for standard cell potentials (PAG8; HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Calculate standard cell potential from E° values
Sub_topics.description: Calculate standard cell potential E°cell by combining two standard electrode potentials; identify cathode/anode based on E° values and direction of spontaneous reaction.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Predict feasibility using E°cell; limitations (kinetics, concentration)
Sub_topics.description: Predict feasibility of redox reaction using standard cell potentials; explain limitations due to kinetics and non-standard concentrations; relate to Nernst-type reasoning qualitatively (M0.3; HSW6).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Modern storage cells and electrode potentials
Sub_topics.description: Apply electrode potential principles to modern storage cells; details and equations provided in exams; evaluate benefits vs risks (toxicity/fire hazards especially Li-based cells) (HSW9).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Fuel cells: voltage from fuel + oxygen; electrode changes
Sub_topics.description: Explain that a fuel cell uses energy from reaction of a fuel with oxygen to create a voltage and describe changes at each electrode; recall of specific fuel cell equations not required; relevant data supplied.

Topics.Strand: Module 5 – Physical chemistry and transition elements

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Electron configurations of Period 4 d-block atoms and ions
Sub_topics.description: Deduce electron configurations of Period 4 d-block elements Sc–Zn and their ions given atomic number and charge; use full subshell notation (e.g. Fe: 1s2 2s2 2p6 3s2 3p6 3d6 4s2) (see 2.2.1(d)).
Define transition elements as d-block elements that form at least one ion with an incomplete d-subshell; identify Ti–Cu as transition elements by this definition.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Multiple oxidation states in transition elements
Sub_topics.description: Illustrate using at least two transition elements that they show more than one oxidation state in compounds/ions; relate to redox behaviour (see also 5.3.1(k)).
Illustrate that transition metals form coloured ions; no detail of electronic transitions required; connect to qualitative analysis observations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Catalysis by transition metals and compounds
Sub_topics.description: Illustrate catalytic behaviour of transition elements and their compounds and importance in industrial manufacture; examples include Cu2+ catalysing Zn + acids, MnO2 decomposition of H2O2; no mechanistic details required; evaluate benefits vs toxicity risks (HSW9).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ligand definition and coordinate bonding; bidentate ligands
Sub_topics.description: Explain and use term ligand as species forming coordinate (dative covalent) bond to metal ion/metal; include bidentate ligands; examples: H2O, Cl−, NH3 (monodentate) and en (NH2CH2CH2NH2) (bidentate); other ligands may be introduced in exams.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Complex ions and coordination number; octahedral and 4-coordinate shapes
Sub_topics.description: Use terms complex ion and coordination number; give examples of 6-coordinate octahedral complexes (e.g. [Cu(H2O)6]2+, [Fe(H2O)6]3+) and 4-coordinate complexes that are tetrahedral (e.g. [CuCl4]2−, [CoCl4]2−) or square planar (Pt complexes such as Pt(NH3)2Cl2); link to shape prediction (M4.1, M4.2).
Describe and interpret cis–trans stereoisomerism in complexes (e.g. Pt(NH3)2Cl2); draw 3-D diagrams; relate to earlier E/Z concepts (M4.1, M4.2, M4.3; HSW8).

Describe optical isomerism in complexes, especially with bidentate/multidentate ligands (e.g. [Ni(en)3]2+); recognise non-superimposable mirror images; draw 3-D diagrams (M4.1, M4.2, M4.3; see also 6.2.2(c)).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cisplatin: anticancer action by DNA binding
Sub_topics.description: Explain use of cis-platin as anti-cancer drug and its action by binding to DNA preventing cell division; evaluate benefits vs side effects (HSW9).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ligand substitution of [Cu(H2O)6]2+ with NH3/Cl− (colour changes)
Sub_topics.description: Describe ligand substitution reactions and colour changes: formation of [Cu(NH3)4(H2O)2]2+ and [CuCl4]2− from [Cu(H2O)6]2+; write equations using complex formulae.
Describe ligand substitution and colour changes forming [Cr(NH3)6]3+ from [Cr(H2O)6]3+; write complex equations; link to precipitation/complex formation with NH3 in 5.3.1(j).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Haemoglobin: ligand substitution with O2 and CO
Sub_topics.description: Explain biochemical importance of iron in haemoglobin including ligand substitution involving O2 and CO; relate to competitive binding and physiological effects.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Precipitation: Cu2+, Fe2+, Fe3+, Mn2+, Cr3+ with NaOH/NH3
Sub_topics.description: Describe reactions (including ionic equations) and colour changes when aqueous Cu2+, Fe2+, Fe3+, Mn2+, Cr3+ react with aqueous NaOH and aqueous NH3 to form hydroxide precipitates; accept complexed/non-complexed formulae for reactants/products as specified; recognise solubilities/colours.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Excess reagents: complex formation and amphoterism (Cr)
Sub_topics.description: Describe further reactions in excess NaOH/NH3: with excess NaOH only Cr(OH)3 dissolves to [Cr(OH)6]3−; with excess NH3 only Cr(OH)3 and Cu(OH)2 form [Cr(NH3)6]3+ and [Cu(NH3)4(H2O)2]2+ respectively; include observations and equations.

Describe redox interconversions between Fe2+ and Fe3+ with colour changes; example reagents: Fe2+ oxidised with H+/MnO4− and Fe3+ reduced with I−; equations may be constructed using half-equations/oxidation numbers rather than recalled.

Describe redox interconversions between Cr3+ and Cr2O7²− with colour changes; example reagents: Cr3+ oxidised with H2O2/OH−; Cr2O7²− reduced with Zn/H+; construct equations using half-equations/oxidation numbers.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cu2+ reduction to Cu+ and Cu+ disproportionation
Sub_topics.description: Describe reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+ (e.g. with I−) and disproportionation of Cu+ to Cu2+ and Cu in aqueous conditions; include colour/solid observations; construct redox equations as needed.

Interpret and predict unfamiliar reactions of transition metal ions including ligand substitution, precipitation and redox; use principles of complex stability, oxidation states, and reagent behaviour.

Topics.Strand: Module 5 – Physical chemistry and transition elements

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Identify anions CO3²−, Cl−, Br−, I−, SO4²−
Sub_topics.description: Carry out qualitative analysis on test-tube scale to identify anions CO3²−, Cl−, Br−, I−, SO4²− in unknown compounds, using correct sequence and confirmatory tests (see 3.1.4(a)); record observations and write ionic equations where appropriate (PAG4; HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Identify cations NH4+, Cu2+, Fe2+, Fe3+, Mn2+, Cr3+
Sub_topics.description: Carry out qualitative analysis on test-tube scale to identify cations NH4+, Cu2+, Fe2+, Fe3+, Mn2+, Cr3+ in unknown compounds using NaOH/NH3 tests and warming where required (see 3.1.4(a), 5.3.1(j)); record colour changes/precipitates/solubility; use ionic equations where appropriate (PAG4; HSW4).

Compare Kekulé model of benzene with delocalised model in terms of p-orbital overlap forming delocalised π-system; represent benzene as ring with alternating double bonds or circle-in-hexagon; understand model development (HSW1,7).

Use experimental evidence for delocalised benzene model: equal bond lengths, enthalpy change of hydrogenation (less exothermic than expected for 3 isolated C=C), and resistance to reaction; relate to stability (HSW11).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: IUPAC naming of substituted aromatic compounds
Sub_topics.description: Apply IUPAC rules to name substituted aromatic compounds using locant numbers for substitution positions (e.g. 2,4-dinitromethylbenzene); systematic naming for multiple substituents (HSW8).
Describe electrophilic substitution of aromatic compounds by nitration using concentrated HNO3 with concentrated H2SO4; write equations and identify products for monosubstitution where appropriate.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Halogenation of arenes with halogen carrier
Sub_topics.description: Describe electrophilic substitution of arenes with halogens in presence of halogen carrier (Fe, FeX3, AlX3); write equations and identify products.

Describe electrophilic substitution of arenes with haloalkanes (alkylation) or acyl chlorides (acylation) using halogen carrier; explain importance in synthesis via forming C–C bond to aromatic ring; link to later C–C formation (6.2.4(d)).

Describe mechanisms of electrophilic substitution in arenes for nitration and halogenation using curly arrows and intermediates; for nitration include formation of NO2+; for halogenation electrophile can be assumed X+; halogen carriers as above (HSW1,2,8).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Why benzene resists bromination vs alkenes
Sub_topics.description: Explain relative resistance of benzene to bromination compared with alkenes in terms of delocalised electron density of benzene π-system vs localised electron density of alkene π bond; relate to stability and reaction type (HSW2,5).

Interpret unfamiliar electrophilic substitution reactions of aromatic compounds and predict mechanisms; use supplied extra information to identify electrophile, catalyst, directing effects where relevant.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Phenol weak acidity (NaOH reacts; carbonates do not)
Sub_topics.description: Explain weak acidity of phenols: phenol neutralises with NaOH but does not react with carbonates; relate to acid strength and equilibrium; apply equations (PAG7; see also 5.1.3(b)).
Describe electrophilic substitution of phenol with bromine to form 2,4,6-tribromophenol; include conditions and observations (e.g. decolourisation, precipitate).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Phenol nitration with dilute HNO3 (2- and 4-nitrophenol mixture)
Sub_topics.description: Describe nitration of phenol with dilute nitric acid to give mixture of 2-nitrophenol and 4-nitrophenol; note does not require conc. HNO3 or conc. H2SO4 catalyst; write equations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Why phenol reacts faster than benzene (lone pair donation)
Sub_topics.description: Explain relative ease of electrophilic substitution of phenol vs benzene due to oxygen lone pair donation into π-system; explain in terms of increased susceptibility of ring to electrophilic attack (not intermediate stability) (HSW2,5).

Explain and apply directing effects in electrophilic substitution: electron-donating groups (OH, NH2) direct to 2 and 4 positions; electron-withdrawing groups (NO2) direct to 3 position; other groups not required but may be supplied (HSW5).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Predict aromatic substitution products using directing groups
Sub_topics.description: Predict substitution products of aromatic compounds using directing effects and explain importance to organic synthesis (see also 6.2.5).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Oxidation of aldehydes to carboxylic acids
Sub_topics.description: Describe oxidation of aldehydes to carboxylic acids using Cr2O7²−/H+ (K2Cr2O7/H2SO4); use [O] and [H] notation in organic redox equations (PAG7).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: NaBH4 reduction of carbonyls to alcohols
Sub_topics.description: Describe nucleophilic addition reduction of aldehydes/ketones using NaBH4 to form alcohols; recognise functional group change and product type.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: HCN addition to carbonyls to form hydroxynitriles
Sub_topics.description: Describe nucleophilic addition of HCN (generated from NaCN(aq)/H+(aq)) to aldehydes/ketones to form hydroxynitriles; link to chain extension and nitrile chemistry (see 6.2.4(b)).

Give mechanisms for nucleophilic addition of NaBH4 and HCN to carbonyl compounds: for NaBH4 treat nucleophile as hydride H− then protonation by H2O; for HCN initial attack by CN− then protonation using H2O or H+; show curly arrows, dipoles, tetrahedral intermediate (HSW1,2,8).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: 2,4-DNP test for carbonyls and derivative melting point ID
Sub_topics.description: Use 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazine (2,4-DNP) to detect carbonyl group; identify carbonyl compound from melting point of derivative; equation and derivative structure not required (PAG7; HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Tollens’ test for aldehydes vs ketones
Sub_topics.description: Use Tollens’ reagent (ammoniacal AgNO3) to detect aldehyde group and distinguish aldehydes from ketones; explain in terms of oxidation of aldehydes to carboxylic acids and reduction of Ag+ to Ag; [O] acceptable in equations (PAG7; HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Carboxylic acid solubility via hydrogen bonding
