Sub_topics.description: Explain water solubility of carboxylic acids in terms of hydrogen bonding between –COOH group and water; relate to polarity and intermolecular forces.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Carboxylic acids reactions with metals and bases (aqueous)
Sub_topics.description: Describe reactions of carboxylic acids in aqueous conditions with metals and bases including carbonates, metal oxides, and alkalis; write equations; comparison of acidity of different carboxylic acids not required (PAG7).
Describe esterification of carboxylic acids with alcohols in presence of acid catalyst (e.g. concentrated H2SO4); write equations and recognise equilibrium nature and conditions.
Describe reaction of acid anhydrides with alcohols to form esters; write equations and identify byproducts (carboxylic acids).
Describe hydrolysis of esters in hot aqueous acid to form carboxylic acids and alcohols; write equations; recognise reversible nature and conditions.
Describe hydrolysis of esters in hot aqueous alkali to form carboxylate salts and alcohols; write equations; recognise effectively irreversible due to salt formation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Form acyl chlorides from carboxylic acids (SOCl2)
Sub_topics.description: Describe formation of acyl chlorides from carboxylic acids using thionyl chloride SOCl2; write equations and recognise gaseous byproducts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Acyl chlorides in synthesis (esters, acids, amides)
Sub_topics.description: Use acyl chlorides in synthesis to form esters, carboxylic acids, and primary/secondary amides; include esterification of phenol (phenol not readily esterified by carboxylic acids) and recognise higher reactivity of acyl chlorides.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Amines as bases; salts with dilute acids
Sub_topics.description: Explain basicity of amines as proton acceptance by nitrogen lone pair; write reactions of amines with dilute inorganic acids (e.g. HCl(aq)) to form ammonium salts; comparison of basicity of different amines not required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prepare aliphatic amines from haloalkanes + ethanolic NH3/amines
Sub_topics.description: Describe preparation of aliphatic amines by substitution of haloalkanes with excess ethanolic ammonia and with amines; include formation of primary amines from NH3 and secondary/tertiary from amines; understand product mixtures and role of excess NH3.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prepare aromatic amines by reducing nitroarenes (Sn/HCl)
Sub_topics.description: Describe preparation of aromatic amines by reduction of nitroarenes using tin and concentrated hydrochloric acid; understand overall change −NO2 to −NH2 and conditions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: α-amino acid general formula and reactions
Sub_topics.description: Use general formula for α-amino acids RCH(NH2)COOH; describe reactions: (i) carboxylic acid group reacts with alkalis and forms esters (link 6.1.3(c)), (ii) amine group reacts with acids; recognise zwitterion behaviour may be implied but not specified here.
Recognise and draw structures of primary and secondary amides; relate to formation from acyl chlorides and amines (see 6.1.3(f), 6.2.3).
Explain optical isomerism as stereoisomerism due to non-superimposable mirror images about a chiral centre; draw 3-D representations; relate to stereochemistry concepts (M4.2, M4.3; HSW1,8).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Identify chiral centres in organic molecules
Sub_topics.description: Identify chiral centres in any organic molecule; determine whether carbon has four different substituents using 2-D/3-D representations (M4.2, M4.3).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Condensation polymerisation to polyesters and polyamides
Sub_topics.description: Explain condensation polymerisation to form polyesters and polyamides from carboxylic acids/dicarboxylic acids (or acyl chlorides) with alcohols/diols or amines/diamines; do not need to recall specific commercial polymer structures or monomers.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hydrolysis of ester links in polyesters
Sub_topics.description: Describe acid and base hydrolysis of ester groups in polyesters; write generalized equations and identify products (diols, dicarboxylic acids or salts).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hydrolysis of amide links in polyamides
Sub_topics.description: Describe acid and base hydrolysis of amide groups in polyamides; write generalized equations and identify products (diamines/ammonium salts and dicarboxylic acids/salts).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Polymer structure questions: repeat units, monomers, type
Sub_topics.description: Predict for addition and condensation polymerisation: (i) repeat unit from given monomer(s), (ii) monomer(s) needed for given polymer section, (iii) type of polymerisation; link to addition polymer content (4.1.3(j)).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: C–C bond formation to extend carbon chain
Sub_topics.description: Explain use of carbon–carbon bond formation in synthesis to increase carbon chain length; recognise strategic importance in multi-step routes (see 6.1.1(d), 6.1.2(b)).
Describe formation of nitriles via nucleophilic substitution of haloalkanes with CN− in ethanol; include SN2 mechanism with curly arrows as in 4.2.2(c); link to chain extension by one carbon.
Describe formation of hydroxynitriles by nucleophilic addition of HCN to carbonyl compounds; include mechanism link to 6.1.2(c) and show C–C bond formation; recognise introduces −CN group.
Describe reduction of nitriles (from 6.2.4(b)) using H2/Ni to form amines; write equations and identify primary amine products.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Acid hydrolysis of nitriles to carboxylic acids
Sub_topics.description: Describe acid hydrolysis of nitriles to carboxylic acids; write equations and recognise need for heating/reflux and acidic conditions; identify ammonium salt byproduct.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Friedel–Crafts alkylation/acylation to form substituted arene C–C bond
Sub_topics.description: Describe formation of substituted aromatic C–C bonds via Friedel–Crafts alkylation (haloalkane) and acylation (acyl chloride) in presence of halogen carrier; link to 6.1.1(d).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prepare/purify organic solids (reflux, filtration, recrystallisation, mp, TLC)
Sub_topics.description: Use techniques/procedures for preparation and purification of organic solids: organic preparation using Quickfit, distillation and reflux; purification by filtration under reduced pressure, recrystallisation; measure melting points; use TLC/paper chromatography as appropriate; conduct risk assessment (PAG6; HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Identify functional groups; predict properties/reactions (Module 6 set)
Sub_topics.description: For organic molecules containing several functional groups (including those introduced in Module 6), identify each functional group and predict properties and reactions; integrate knowledge across modules (HSW3).

Devise multi-stage synthetic routes by applying transformations between all functional groups studied throughout the specification; interpret additional information on exam papers extending reaction toolkit; justify sequencing and reagents (HSW3).
Interpret one-way TLC chromatograms using Rf values (Rf = distance moved by spot / distance moved by solvent front); compare substances and assess purity/identity (M3.1; PAG6; HSW3).
Interpret gas chromatograms in terms of retention times to identify components based on time to elute; relate to interactions with stationary phase (M3.1, M3.2; HSW3).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Gas chromatography: composition from peak areas and calibration
Sub_topics.description: Interpret gas chromatograms to determine amounts/proportions of mixture components using peak integration values (supplied) and external calibration curves to confirm concentrations (M3.1, M3.2; HSW3).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Functional group test: alkenes with bromine
Sub_topics.description: Identify alkenes via reaction with bromine (decolourisation) as test for C=C; apply to unknowns and write equations where appropriate (PAG7; HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Functional group test: haloalkanes with AgNO3/ethanol
Sub_topics.description: Identify haloalkanes using aqueous AgNO3 in ethanol; interpret precipitate formation (AgX) and rate differences; link to hydrolysis mechanism context (PAG7; HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Functional group test: phenols (weak acid, no carbonate reaction)
Sub_topics.description: Identify phenols by weak acidity (react with NaOH) but no reaction with CO3²−; distinguish from carboxylic acids which do react with carbonates (PAG7; HSW4).
Identify carbonyl compounds (aldehydes/ketones) by reaction with 2,4-DNP to give precipitate; interpret positive test (PAG7; HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Functional group test: aldehydes with Tollens’ reagent
Sub_topics.description: Identify aldehydes using Tollens’ reagent (silver mirror/Ag precipitate); distinguish from ketones; relate to redox process (PAG7; HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Acidified dichromate test: primary/secondary alcohols and aldehydes
Sub_topics.description: Use acidified dichromate (Cr2O7²−/H+) to test and distinguish primary/secondary alcohols and aldehydes (oxidised; orange to green) from tertiary alcohols/ketones (no reaction under test conditions); interpret outcomes (PAG7; HSW4).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Functional group test: carboxylic acids with carbonates
Sub_topics.description: Identify carboxylic acids by reaction with CO3²− producing CO2 effervescence; write equations and distinguish from phenols (PAG7; HSW4).
From proton-decoupled 13C NMR spectrum, determine number of carbon environments in molecule; interpret symmetry and unique carbon sites (M3.1; HSW3,5).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: 13C NMR: carbon environment types from chemical shift
Sub_topics.description: Use 13C chemical shift values (provided on Data Sheet) to identify types of carbon environments (e.g. carbonyl, aromatic, C–O, alkyl) for functional groups in A level spec; restrict to studied functional groups (M3.1).
Use 13C NMR information to propose possible structures consistent with number/type of carbon environments; integrate with other data where provided (M3.1; HSW3,5).
From high-resolution 1H NMR spectrum, determine number of proton environments; interpret equivalence and symmetry; note aromatic splitting patterns not required (M3.1; HSW3,5).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: 1H NMR: proton environment types from chemical shift
Sub_topics.description: Use 1H chemical shift values (provided on Data Sheet) to identify types of proton environments (e.g. alkyl, adjacent to electronegative atoms, aldehyde, aromatic); identify aromatic protons by shift but not analyse their splitting (M3.1).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: 1H NMR: integration and relative proton numbers
Sub_topics.description: Determine relative numbers of each type of proton from relative peak areas using integration traces or ratio numbers when required; convert ratios to actual proton counts consistent with formula (M3.1).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: 1H NMR: spin–spin splitting and n+1 rule
Sub_topics.description: Use spin–spin splitting patterns and n + 1 rule to determine number of non-equivalent adjacent protons; interpret multiplicities (singlet, doublet, triplet, etc.) and coupling context (M3.1).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: 1H NMR: propose structures from full spectrum
Sub_topics.description: Use combined 1H NMR features (chemical shift, integration, splitting) to propose possible molecular structures restricted to functional groups in A level spec; incorporate aromatic protons identification without detailed splitting (M3.1; HSW3,5).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Predict 13C or 1H NMR spectra from structure
Sub_topics.description: Predict features of a 13C NMR or 1H NMR spectrum for a given molecule: number of environments and approximate chemical shift regions; for 1H include expected splitting for non-aromatic regions (M3.1).
Explain use of tetramethylsilane (TMS) as standard reference for chemical shift measurements; chemical shift δ measured relative to TMS at 0 ppm.
Explain need for deuterated solvents (e.g. CDCl3) when running NMR spectra to avoid proton signals from solvent and provide lock signal.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: D2O exchange to identify O–H and N–H protons
Sub_topics.description: Identify O–H and N–H protons by proton exchange using D2O; explain disappearance/broadening changes in 1H NMR after D2O shake.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Deduce structure from combined EA, MS, IR, NMR
Sub_topics.description: Deduce structures of organic compounds using combined analytical data: elemental analysis, mass spectra, IR spectra, and NMR spectra; reference data supplied on Data Sheet; restricted to functional groups studied; mass spectra of organic halogen compounds not required (M3.1; HSW3,5,6).
